title: Usage of the Kalman filter for data cleaning of sensor data

author: Klemen Kenda, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: And Clement, and this is a joint work that I did with Mushclient.
And yes, now in the back and we will change a bit domain because we will move to the sensor data here.

So we have addressed the problem of the data cleaning and we tried to use an quite old algorithm, Kalman filtering, and in this presentation I will go just briefly through what data cleaning keys, so it should be.
I will present Kalman filter.
I will tell how we adapt it for the sensor data and then I will briefly show some results.
So.
Sensor data today is cheap, which means that we have big amount of this data we need to deal with it fast, efficiently.

And it also means that a lot of this data is is noisy, noisy in a way that sensor measurements are not accurate so noisy in a way that the information does not come from the sensor to the our system to our data acquisition acquisition system.
And there are many errors and what we want to do with the data cleaning.
We want to detect these errors we want to.
Estimate whether we have a problem with the sensor and we want to eliminate this error, either by replacing the.
The values with some model that we have.
Or either to remove them and there is also a bit of other.
Function that data cleaning should do, but it is small bound to the matter of syntactic evaluation of this data.
OK, so the first thing that we need to establish is that where to put data cleaning into the system.
Ideally we would one day to cleaning to be as low as possible, so maybe even at the resource tier in multi tier architecture.
So at the data source.

But we determined that this maybe is not the best solution 'cause if we want to go to the sensor itself there are different protocols and implementation would take quite a lot of time so this is one reason why.
Put it higher and the other reason is that a lot of times cause of sensor failure or failure of the information from the sensor is also in here.

So at the data tier we expect the information to be safe, sort of speaking, and there we intend to put our data cleaning component which also contains a graphical user interface which serves to the purpose that we can adjust the algorithms to.
To work on our data.
OK, so the common filter is more than 50 years old.
It's an old algorithm, not very complex.
It was developed by a Hungarian mathematician, Rudolf Kalman, but also some work has been done by his contemporaries or even in the late 19th century.
But Rudolf Kalman, he had an opportunity to work in the NASA program and this his filter was actually used to track the missiles in the Apollo program.
So I think that maybe this is also how.
One of the reasons why he's going to this filter so the usages of the Kalman filter that we meet every day in our life are, for example GPS navigation in our cell phone.
In our smartphones, that navigation uses common filter to smooth to smooth, and the trajectory for example.
We use it with the electronic compass.
There are a lot of applications in computer vision and so on.

Uh-huh, so here is an example for the usage of this common filter for the tracking we see here it with the red dots we see the data from the GPS device which is noisy, so it is distributed a bit around the correct value and then we have the auto meter data which is which is smoother but it's not correct.
Kalman filter has a functionality that it can join these two datasets that it can.
Remove most of the noise and it creates with this green line a smooth trajectory of the vehicle.
For example, on the.
A smooth trajectory of the vehicle.
OK, to explain how?
What is the idea behind the Kalman filter?
Maybe we should go back to the first lesson of physics.
Usually this lesson in Slovenian school starts with the.
With the measurements we want to measure some phenomena.
For example, depth of the water and if we want to estimate.
If you measure this one time, we don't know if we measured the correct value because this value, the measurement is biased by some noise or maybe over some systematic failure.
We need to take multiple measures and then what we do we create we calculate an average and also with an average we can calculate the standard deviations.
It's approximately what Kalman filter does, but not under static data points, but rather on a dynamic model for example and model of the vehicle.
Driving around where we have the position of the vehicle, we have its velocity and then we calculate its future position from that data.
OK, basically what we have we are dealing with this process and this process has two layers.
This is the layer of measurements.
For example, let's take the desired temperature measurements and the layer above.
Below is a hidden layer.
This layer actually contains the real state of the system.
So we have sensor measurements temperature.
The temperature is biased by some noise and this data.
These are the states of the system which contain the true.
Or the better estimate for the true values?
OK, this process is called Gauss.

Marko Marko means that each consequent states is only dependent, but by its from its previous state and told the Arrows that we see in this process are actually they bring Gaussian noise into this process.
The algorithm is online, which is very good reason why to use it on a sensor data on a data stream 'cause this is also happens online and what is cool about the algorithm?
Is that it has?
Two phases, the prediction phase, which means that we can for a short time period predict what the future will values will be.
This is a functionality that we will take advantage of with the data cleaning and then we have the correction phase which basically.
Takes the prediction of our model.
It takes the concrete measurements and then calculate the new better approximation for this.
And here another thing is that this filter as it is online it adapts to the data.
So if the system or the model behind changes a little bit or parameter of the model change a little bit, this system will adapt quite fast.
Depends of course on the.
Initial conditions.
OK.

So I have thought a little bit about the properties of the sensor data that I think is that, for example, if we have a sensor for the temperature, this temperature from the environment will maybe come every two minutes or every minute or even faster, and what we can expect from this data is that actually we will not have any big changes if there will be some big changes in the data.
This will most probably mean that there is some problem with the measurement.
So for that purpose we suggest to use a second degree model, which is quite simple.
Maybe some of you have not noticed in this parameters the equations for the accelerated movement.
OK, let's go slowly.
So this is the prediction and we calculate the prediction for the next time period from the previous state, and only think that tells us how to do this prediction is this.
Matrix and this matrix is basically our model.
Now let's go to our state vector, for example, that we have temperature.
Our state vector will be.
We have three components.
First component will be the action model.
Actual estimate for the temperature.
OK, so if we have this second parameter will be his first temporary derivative and this third parameter will be its second temporary derivative.
Basically what we get from this model is a sort of 2nd degree polynomial that will approximate our phenomena in this.
Locali
OK, and this how to detect outliers here when you have a model is quite straightforward.
What we do we have a state of the system.

We run the prediction, we get some estimate for the prediction and around this prediction we create a virtual gap that we say when a measurement falls inside this gap, the we estimate that the measurement was OK and we use it to calculate the new state of the.
Of the system and if it falls outside as it happened here, we say that it's not OK. We discard it.
We replace the value with the.
Value calculated from the model and we proceed with the.
With the algorithm.
We have done some preliminary work on the environmental data on the temperature data.
Here is the example.
Temperature is from the July and August and what we do here, here.
These are the real measurements, the red line and around these measurements we calculate a boundary higher boundary which is in blue and the lower boundary which is in green and these boundaries.
Then we compare them to the real measurements and then decide whether.
If they fall outside, we can we conclude that it is a sensor failure?
If not, then we consider them OK.
So we see here we have had a failure in the sensor data.
It has fallen outside the boundary.
We detected an outlier and basically.
This is it so.
This common algorithm is fairly.
It's not demanding to be used.
We only need sensor measurements so that it can run.
We don't need any data integration, we don't need which sensors are around and so on.
It is self sufficient.
It's simple to use, but it's very difficult to create to found the correct start parameters.
So there is a lot of work to be done in the initialization phase of the filter.
Sampling.
Yeah, usually the mathematical correct way would be that you would know the correct.

The correct state of the system in the beginning contribute would estimate the variance of that round, and then you can go on, but usually you don't know this, so it's yeah it would be very nice to have some method that you could optimize the parameters according to the final gain.
Yeah, OK, we have also encountered some instability in the sorry.
In the system, so if.
The algorithm by some case detects are false negative, so actually a measurement that is correct but falls outside because of the something happen externally to the phenomena we are measuring.
Measuring it might happen that our our algorithm would fail, so we can see here that temperature cannot fall below.
90 degrees Celsius in minus, and in this case we propose to just do the following.
We extend the width of the gap in this system and.
It's not mathematically correct, but then the next measurements falls within this gap and the parameters of the filter.
Update correctly.
OK, so just in conclusions, we have used an algorithm.
We have used it for a new purpose.
We tested a few models of for this algorithm and we decided for the second degree model based on the data that we have.
We have suggested solving the instability problem, but this is also part of the future work that we have.
I have just shown briefly the idea, but we need to establish the mechanisms behind and make this more rigid.
I.
As I already mentioned, the initial initialization of the filter is very complex.
We have some idea how to how to solve this problem, not mathematically correct, but efficient in sort of engineering way.
And one thing I would like to mention, although this algorithm is quite well known, it has been also some improvement has been done with this.
Within this Institute there is a new algorithm which actually does not demand to have.
The user to know the Department of Physics.
Yes, the algorithm and also in cooperation with faculty of mathematics and physics.
It's an algorithm that does not require the initial state to be known.
It just takes in the measurement and then after a certain amount of measurements it estimates the internal state, the variance and then the algorithm can run in the common way and you use this.
We have already implemented this second algorithm, but I have not yet used it for this purpose.
Yeah, yeah.
